elements.title: Answer the following comprehension questions about the text.

elements.name: question1
elements.title: When do you become legally competent?
elements.correctAnswer: In Switzerland, legal capacity begins at the time of birth.

elements.name: question2
elements.title: Who is capable of acting?
elements.correctAnswer: A person has full capacity to act if he or she is capable of judgment (approx. from the age of 14) and of legal age (from the age of 18).

elements.name: panel2
elements.title: Answer the following comprehension questions about the text.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: What is the difference between legal capacity and capacity to act?
elements.correctAnswer: You have legal capacity from birth. This means that you can have rights and obligations. Capacity to act requires the ability to make judgments and the age of majority. If both are present, a person has the capacity to enter into a contract, to marry, to sue, to prosecute and to commit an offense.

elements.name: question5
elements.title: Which persons are considered to have limited legal capacity and how does this manifest itself?
elements.correctAnswer: All persons who are capable of judgment but have not yet reached the age of majority are considered to have limited legal capacity. This means that a person may carry out everyday transactions independently, but must consult their legal representative for important actions.
